citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On Tuesday November 1, 2022, Tic, a lemur, was seen by the veterinarian for a dental cleaning and removal of a mass.
The discharge instructions stated that Tic was found to be thin and that weight should be monitored and reported back to
the veterinarian. The licensee stated that they had not monitored the weight due to difficulties in handling Tic. In addition,
the facility had not contacted the veterinarian to seek guidance on alternatives to weighing Tic.
Not following care instructions can result in continued or worsening health issues for Tic.
It is essential that guidance and care plans received from the veterinarian be fully followed to ensure proper care of all
animals.
Correct by: November 10, 2023

One white fox is housed in a large outdoor enclosure during the day. The fox is transported in a crate to the office at the
end of the day. The fox is then transferred to a 30"x48" metal wire crate. The crate has a litter pan which reduces the
available floor space. The fox is housed in the crate when the park is closed for approximately 16-20 hours a day. Being
handled in this manner can cause behavioral stress and unnecessary discomfort for the fox.
Ensure that all animals are housed and handled in a manner that prevents stress and discomfort.
Correct by: November 10, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The enrichment plan developed by the veterinarian for the non-human primates was not available during the inspection.
Part of the plan information was available but it was unclear to inspectors what actions were being taken to promote
enrichment.
Non-human Primates that not provided adequate enrichment are at risk of stress, discomfort and developing harmful
behaviors.
Ensure that the veterinarian directed enrichment plan is utilized for the non-human primates and that the plan is available
for review during inspections and use by facility staff.
Correct by: November 10, 2023

Enclosures had sharp points that have the potential to injure the animals.
Areas of concern are as follows:
* There is a cover approximately 5"x5" on the front wall of the enclosure housing 5 turacos. The covering has several
sharp points poking into the enclosure. The points could injure the birds in the enclosure.
* In the aviary, there are 25 cut trees strapped to support poles as perches. The trees are strapped with a twisted wire
which has sharp points. The sharp points could injure the birds in the enclosure.
* In the barnyard, there are scratch brushes screwed to wooden fenced square around a tree. The screws are sticking
through the boards inside the square around the tree. There were two chickens inside the square during the inspection.
These sharp points could injure the animals.
* There was a broken board along the bottom of one of the small barns in the barn yard. A screw was sticking out along
the bottom of the area near the doorway and is a sharp point which could injure the animals.
Sharp points within an enclosure can injure the animals housed therein.
Repair enclosures so that the enclosure is structurally sound and does not cause injury.
Correct by: December 10, 2023

One goat was being housed in a corn crib. The goat had been separated due to illness awaiting veterinary care. The corn
crib does not have a wind break and there was no other shelter available for the goat. Lack of shelter from the wind can
cause discomfort and prolong or worsen disease,
Provide appropriate shelter for all animals housed outdoors.
Correct by: November 10, 2023

One enclosure, housing a fox, does not have a complete perimeter fence. The pen has two access doors at the back of
the pen. The doors open to an alley way and is only enclosed on three sides. Two sides are made by the building behind
the pen and the back of the enclosure. The third side is a fencing panel between the enclosure and the building behind.
The panel is not secured to the building wall and presents a gap for escape. The fourth side is open to the driveway and
the rest of the park.
A perimeter fence that can act as secondary containment is required for the enclosure.
Secondary containment ensures safety for the animal in case of escape from primary enclosure. Escape puts animals at
risk of severe injury.
Repair and complete the perimeter fence to ensure a secure secondary containment area.
Correct by: December 10, 2023

Pelleted food is stored in bags on a pallet in the shop area. There was loose feed scattered on the floor around the pallet.
Loose feed attracts vermin which can contaminate the feed. Contaminated feed may result in disease and or reduced
intake due to unpalatability.
Keep the area clean to prevent contamination of the feed.
Correct by: November 10, 2023
The cooler used to refrigerate fruit and vegetables for the animals has old moldy food on the floor under the shelving. The
moldy food and waste on the floor can contaminate the food stored in the cooler. Contaminated food can result in reduced
intake and may cause illness in the animals.
Keep the cooler clean to prevent contamination.
Correct by: November 10, 2023

There are four nest boxes for birds along the bottom of the one building in the barnyard. There are vinyl strips for
windbreak for three of the boxes. One box is missing the vinyl and is directly open to the wind.
Insufficient shelter for the birds can cause discomfort.
Repair the flaps on the nest box to provide windbreak.
Correct by: December 10, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
An enrichment plan has not been developed for the birds. Without adequate enrichment, birds are at risk of stress and
developing harmful behaviors.
Develop, document and follow an enrichment plan for the birds. The plan must be approved by the veterinarian.
Correct by: December 10, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
One enclosure, housing 32 Lovebirds and one African Ringneck Pheasant has perches and nest boxes. There is
accumulated feces on the nest boxes. The birds have been in the enclosure for approximately one month. Park staff
indicated that the nest boxes aren't cleaned until the birds are moved back to the aviary. One month accumulation of
feces on one of the boxes has partially covered the top of the box and on one section was approximately 1/4" deep. Not
cleaning for another 6-7 months will result in additional accumulation. Accumulated feces is a risk of disease for the birds.
The accumulation on top of the boxes should be scraped off on a regular basis to reduce disease risks.
Correct by: November 10, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Two indoor pens housing 2 Superb Starlings and one Sun Conure respectively have cobwebs and loose spray foam
insulation from the ceiling. The accumulation of debris indicates the enclosure is not being sanitized as often as
necessary. Frequent sanitizing is required to prevent disease and illness.
Thoroughly sanitize enclosures to ensure prevention of accumulation to reduce risk of disease.
Correct by: November 10, 2023

One cockatiel is housed in an enclosure in a flock of 51 total birds. This bird is missing feathers around the entire
circumference of its neck. The flock was housed in a large outdoor aviary providing adequate space for separation during
the summer and has been penned in a smaller enclosure for a month. Lack of neck feathers, especially on the back side
of the neck where the bird itself cannot reach with its beak, is consistent with the plumage in this are being plucked by
other birds. Plucking by other birds can cause stress and injury to the bird. Evaluate the flock for signs of additional
plucking or other signs of incompatibility. Ensure that all birds are housed with compatible birds and provide adequate
separation of any that are not compatible.
Correct by: November 10, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with park staff.
n
